6 /// <summary>
7 /// Linear Regression Slope
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// Returns the Slope component of the Linear Regression line.
11 /// Indicates the speed and direction of the trend.
12 /// <list type="bullet">
13 /// <item><description>Positive: Upward trend.</description></item>
14 /// <item><description>Negative: Downward trend.</description></item>
15 /// <item><description>Steepness indicates strength.</description></item>
16 /// </list>
17 /// </remarks>
18 public class LinRegSlopeIndicator
19 {
20 public int Period { get; }
21 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
22​
23 public LinRegSlopeIndicator(int period = 20)
24 {
25 Period = period;
26 }
27​
28 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
29 {
30 Values.Clear();
31 var c = new List<CandleData>(candles);
32 if (c.Count == 0) return;
33​
34 for (int i = 0; i < c.Count; i++)
35 {
36 if (i < Period - 1) { Values.Add(null); continue; }
37​
38 decimal sumX = 0, sumY = 0, sumXY = 0, sumX2 = 0;
39 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
40 {
41 decimal x = j; // 0 to Period-1
42 decimal y = c[i - Period + 1 + j].Close;
43 sumX += x;
44 sumY += y;
45 sumXY += x * y;
46 sumX2 += x * x;
47 }
48​
49 decimal n = Period;
50 decimal denom = n * sumX2 - sumX * sumX;
51 if (denom == 0) { Values.Add(0); continue; }
52​
53 decimal slope = (n * sumXY - sumX * sumY) / denom;
54 Values.Add(slope);
55 }
56 }
57​
58 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 20)
59 {
60 var lrs = new LinRegSlopeIndicator(period);
61 lrs.Calculate(candles);
62 return lrs.Values;
63 }
64 }
65}

1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (LinRegSlopeIndicator)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Linear Regression Slope Indicator.
7// We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8// line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9//
10// [Core Concepts]
11//
12// 1. What is LinRegSlope?
13// [What] This indicator outputs ONLY the slope of the linear regression line.
14// [Why] The slope tells us the DIRECTION and STRENGTH of the trend.
15// - Positive slope → Uptrend
16// - Negative slope → Downtrend
17// - Near zero → Sideways/Range-bound
18//
19// 2. Slope vs. LSMA
20// [LSMA] Outputs the endpoint VALUE of the regression line.
21// [LinRegSlope] Outputs the SLOPE (angle/steepness) of the line.
22//
23// [Visual]
24// Y = a + b × X
25// │ ╱ <- b (slope) is the angle
26// │ ╱
27// │ ╱
28// │ ╱
29// │──────╱ <- a (intercept)
30// └─────────────── X
31//
32// 3. Interpretation
33//
34// | Slope Value | Meaning |
35// |------------------|-----------------------------------|
36// | > 0 (positive) | Prices trending UP |
37// | < 0 (negative) | Prices trending DOWN |
38// | ≈ 0 | No clear trend (sideways) |
39// | Large |slope| | Strong trend |
40// | Small |slope| | Weak trend |
41//
42// =============================================================================
43​
44using System;
45using System.Collections.Generic;
46​
47namespace TechnicalIndicators
48{
49 // =============================================================================
50 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container
51 // =============================================================================
52 public readonly record struct CandleData(DateTime Timestamp, decimal Open, decimal High, decimal Low, decimal Close, long Volume);
53​
54 // =============================================================================
55 // Logic Explanation: LinRegSlopeIndicator Class
56 // =============================================================================
57 public class LinRegSlopeIndicator
58 {
59 // -------------------------------------------------------------
60 // Logic Explanation: Configuration
61 // -------------------------------------------------------------
62 public int Period { get; }
63 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
64​
65 // =============================================================================
66 // Logic Explanation: Constructor
67 // =============================================================================
68 public LinRegSlopeIndicator(int period = 20)
69 {
70 if (period <= 0)
71 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period));
72
73 Period = period;
74 }
75​
76 // =============================================================================
77 // Logic Explanation: Main Calculation Method
78 // =============================================================================
79 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
80 {
81 // -------------------------------------------------------------
82 // Step 1: Cleanup & Setup
83 // -------------------------------------------------------------
84 Values.Clear();
85 var c = new List<CandleData>(candles);
86 if (c.Count == 0) return;
87​
88 // -------------------------------------------------------------
89 // Step 2: Main Loop
90 // -------------------------------------------------------------
91 for (int i = 0; i < c.Count; i++)
92 {
93 // [Check] Need 'Period' bars for regression
94 if (i < Period - 1)
95 {
96 Values.Add(null);
97 continue;
98 }
99​
100 // -------------------------------------------------------------
101 // Step 3: Calculate Summations
102 //
103 // [Variables]
104 // X = 0, 1, 2, ..., Period-1 (time index)
105 // Y = Close prices
106 //
107 // [Note] X starts at 0 here (slightly different from LSMA).
108 // The slope formula works regardless of the X offset.
109 // -------------------------------------------------------------
110 decimal sumX = 0, sumY = 0, sumXY = 0, sumX2 = 0;
111​
112 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
113 {
114 decimal x = j;
115 decimal y = c[i - Period + 1 + j].Close;
116​
117 sumX += x;
118 sumY += y;
119 sumXY += x * y;
120 sumX2 += x * x;
121 }
122​
123 // -------------------------------------------------------------
124 // Step 4: Calculate Slope
125 //
126 // [Formula]
127 // denominator = n × ΣX² - (ΣX)²
128 // slope = (n × ΣXY - ΣX × ΣY) / denominator
129 //
130 // [Edge Case] If denominator is 0, return 0.
131 // -------------------------------------------------------------
132 decimal n = Period;
133 decimal denom = n * sumX2 - sumX * sumX;
134​
135 if (denom == 0)
136 {
137 Values.Add(0);
138 continue;
139 }
140​
141 decimal slope = (n * sumXY - sumX * sumY) / denom;
142​
143 Values.Add(slope);
144 }
145 }
146​
147 // =============================================================================
148 // Logic Explanation: Static Convenience Wrapper
149 //
150 // [IPO Block]
151 // Input: IEnumerable<CandleData>, int period
152 // Process: Creates instance, runs Calculate()
153 // Output: List of slope values
154 // =============================================================================
155 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 20)
156 {
157 var lrs = new LinRegSlopeIndicator(period);
158 lrs.Calculate(candles);
159 return lrs.Values;
160 }
161 }
162}

1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (Linear Regression Slope)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Linear Regression Slope Indicator. We explain *why* code is written
7# this way and *how* data transforms line-by-line.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. Price Momentum via Geometry
11# Most momentum indicators (RSI, Momentum) use price differences.
12# This indicator uses "Best Fit Geometry".
13# It draws a straight line through the past N prices calculated via
14# Linear Regression (Least Squares).
15#
16# 2. Minimum Variance
17# The Least Squares line minimizes the distance between the line and the
18# actual price points. It is the "Trendiest" trend line possible.
19#
20# 3. Slope (m) interpretation
21# We extract the Slope (m) from the equation Y = mX + b.
22# - Slope > 0: Prices are trending Up.
23# - Slope < 0: Prices are trending Down.
24# - Slope near 0: Prices are sideways/choppy.
25# - Steep Slope: Strong, aggressive trend.
26#
27# =============================================================================
28​
29# -------------------------------------------------------------
30# Type-Level Explanation: LinRegSlopeIndicator (class)
31#
32# [Why] Encapsulates statistical regression logic.
33# [What] Measures the "Steepness" of the trend.
34# [How] Calculates the slope of the linear regression line fit to prices over a lookback period to measure the rate of change or momentum of the trend.
35# [Who] Trend Following Algos, Momentum Traders.
36# [Where] Heap.
37# -------------------------------------------------------------
38class LinRegSlopeIndicator:
39​
40 # -------------------------------------------------------------
41 # Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
42 #
43 # [Why]
44 # Configuration is standard: How many bars back to fit the line?
45 # -------------------------------------------------------------
46​
47 # -------------------------------------------------------------
48 # Constructor: __init__
49 #
50 # [Input]
51 # - period: int (Window size)
52 #
53 # [Why]
54 # Initialize implementation constants.
55 # -------------------------------------------------------------
56 def __init__(self, period=20):
57
58 # -------------------------------------------------------------
59 # Logic Step 1: Validation
60 # -------------------------------------------------------------
61 if period <= 1:
62 raise ValueError(f"Period must be greater than 1. Received: {period}")
63​
64 self.period = period
65 self.values = []
66​
67​
68 # =============================================================================
69 # IPO: calculate
70 # =============================================================================
71 #
72 # [Input]
73 # - candles: list[dict] (Must have 'close')
74 #
75 # [Process]
76 # 1. Iterate through data with a sliding window.
77 # 2. Map Time to X (0 to N-1). Map Price to Y.
78 # 3. Calculate the component sums (SumX, SumY, SumXY, SumX^2).
79 # 4. Apply Slope Formula: (N*SumXY - SumX*SumY) / (N*SumX2 - SumX^2).
80 #
81 # [Output]
82 # - None (populates self.values)
83 # =============================================================================
84 def calculate(self, candles):
85
86 # -------------------------------------------------------------
87 # Logic Step 1: Reset
88 # -------------------------------------------------------------
89 self.values.clear()
90 count = len(candles)
91
92 if count == 0:
93 return
94​
95 # -------------------------------------------------------------
96 # Logic Step 2: Main Loop
97 #
98 # [Why]
99 # Re-fit the regression line for every single bar.
100 # -------------------------------------------------------------
101 for i in range(count):
102
103 # Logic Step 2.1: Insufficient Data
104 if i < self.period - 1:
105 self.values.append(None)
106 continue
107​
108 # -------------------------------------------------------------
109 # Logic Step 2.2: Accumulate Statistics (O(N^2))
110 #
111 # [Visual] Period=3
112 # Prices: [100, 102, 106]
113 # X: [0, 1, 2] (Using 0-based index helps calculation sometimes,
114 # but slope is invariant to X-shift).
115 # Y: [100, 102, 106]
116 # -------------------------------------------------------------
117 sum_x = 0.0
118 sum_y = 0.0
119 sum_xy = 0.0
120 sum_sq_x = 0.0
121
122 # Iterate through the window [i - period + 1 ... i]
123 for j in range(self.period):
124 # X coordinate (Time Step, 0-based)
125 # Note: Whether we use 0..N-1 or 1..N, the Slope (Steepness) is identical.
126 # Only the Intercept (Height) changes.
127 x = j
128
129 # Y coordinate (Price)
130 idx = i - self.period + 1 + j
131 y = candles[idx]['close']
132
133 sum_x += x
134 sum_y += y
135 sum_xy += (x * y)
136 sum_sq_x += (x * x)
137​
138 # -------------------------------------------------------------
139 # Logic Step 2.3: Solve for Slope
140 #
141 # [Formula]
142 # m = (N * Sum(XY) - Sum(X)*Sum(Y)) / Denominator
143 # Denom = N * Sum(X^2) - (Sum(X))^2
144 # -------------------------------------------------------------
145 n = self.period
146 denominator = (n * sum_sq_x) - (sum_x * sum_x)
147
148 # Division Guard
149 if denominator == 0:
150 self.values.append(0.0)
151 else:
152 slope = ((n * sum_xy) - (sum_x * sum_y)) / denominator
153 self.values.append(slope)
154​
155​
156# =============================================================================
157# Functional Wrapper (Procedural Interface)
158# =============================================================================
159def calculate(candles, period=20):
160 """
161 Computes Slope of the Linear Regression line of the Close prices.
162 """
163 # 1. Instantiation
164 instance = LinRegSlopeIndicator(period)
165
166 # 2. Execution
167 instance.calculate(candles)
168
169 # 3. Extraction
170 return instance.values
